title: datasets
text: This website uses various datasets to demonstrate code. Below are explanations to the datasets and their download links.

title: datasets
text:
Suggestions for Matthew

Houseplant envirpnment characteristics
https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/noneee/houseplant-environment-characteristics

title: Creating tibbles
text: Their are various ways to create tibbles. Below are three methods:

title: Creating tibbles
text:
Code to tibble
When creating a tibble through code you provide the tibble::tibble() function with vectors of identical length. Each vector will become a column.

#Vectors to be used as columns
Day <- c("Mon", "Tue", "Wed")
Month <- rep("January", 3)
Hawks <- c(3,7,2)
Pigeons <- c(52,21,61)
Starlings <- c(1,2,1)
#Create a tibble
tbl <- tibble::tibble(Day, Month, Hawks, Pigeons, Starlings)
#View tibble
#Note that the column names are the same as the vector names
tbl

# A tibble: 3 × 5
  Day   Month   Hawks Pigeons Starlings
  <chr> <chr>   <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>
1 Mon   January     3      52         1
2 Tue   January     7      21         2
3 Wed   January     2      61         1

title: Creating tibbles
text:
data.frame to tibble
Let’s load in the built-in iris data frame and convert it to a tibble.

#Head of iris data.frame
head(iris)

  Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species
1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2  setosa
2          4.9         3.0          1.4         0.2  setosa
3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2  setosa
4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2  setosa
5          5.0         3.6          1.4         0.2  setosa
6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4  setosa

#Coerce to tibble
iris_tbl <- tibble::as_tibble(iris)
#View iris tibble
iris_tbl

# A tibble: 150 × 5
   Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species
          <dbl>       <dbl>        <dbl>       <dbl> <fct>  
 1          5.1         3.5          1.4         0.2 setosa 
 2          4.9         3            1.4         0.2 setosa 
 3          4.7         3.2          1.3         0.2 setosa 
 4          4.6         3.1          1.5         0.2 setosa 
 5          5           3.6          1.4         0.2 setosa 
 6          5.4         3.9          1.7         0.4 setosa 
 7          4.6         3.4          1.4         0.3 setosa 
 8          5           3.4          1.5         0.2 setosa 
 9          4.4         2.9          1.4         0.2 setosa 
10          4.9         3.1          1.5         0.1 setosa 
# ℹ 140 more rows


Note: The iris dataset is built-in to base R. You can see all the pre-loaded datasets in R with data()

title: Creating tibbles
text:
File to tibble
We can use readr’s function read_csv() to read in a file as a tibble. More information: readr
Ensure you have the following file downloaded:

house_plants_dbl <- readr::read_csv(file = "all_plant_details.csv")
house_plants_dbl



Rows: 155 Columns: 33
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (1): common_name
dbl (32): id, seeds, drought_tolerant, salt_tolerant, thorny, invasive, trop...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


# A tibble: 155 × 33
      id common_name        seeds drought_tolerant salt_tolerant thorny invasive
   <dbl> <chr>              <dbl>            <dbl>         <dbl>  <dbl>    <dbl>
 1   425 flowering-maple        0                1             0      1        0
 2   426 flowering-maple        0                1             0      0        0
 3   427 flowering-maple        0                1             0      0        0
 4   428 flowering-maple        0                1             1      0        0
 5   434 Jacob's coat           0                0             0      0        0
 6   502 hot water plant        0                0             0      0        0
 7   540 desert rose            0                1             1      1        0
 8   543 maidenhair fern        0                0             0      0        0
 9   546 delta maidenhair …     0                1             0      0        0
10   549 urn plant              1                1             1      0        0
# ℹ 145 more rows

#   cones <dbl>, fruits <dbl>, edible_fruit <dbl>, leaf <dbl>,

title: NEOF Tidyverse
text:
This is a resource for the R Tidyverse suite of packages. It is intended as a quick one-stop reference for the various tidyverse packages and their functions, also known as a cookbook.
This website does not go into great details rather it provides:
This webpage is split into sections for each of the main packages in tidyverse. These are:

title: NEOF Tidyverse
text:
Package names
To keep consistent we will include the package name of each function used in code. This is carried out like below.

#

title: NEOF Tidyverse
text:
Installation & loading
Ensure you have tidyverse installed and loaded before running commands within the rest of these materials.
You can install all the tidyverse packages with the following command:

install.packages("tidyverse")

Once installed you can load the package suite:

library("tidyverse")

title: NEOF Tidyverse
text:
External links

Tidyverse homepage
R for Data Science (2e): If you want a more structured course this is a good place to start.

title: Tibble
text:
Overview
A tibble (tbl) is a reimagining of the data.frame (df) object. They are described as data.frames that are:

Lazy: They don’t change variable names and they don’t do partial matching.
Surly: They complain more such as when a variable does not exist.

One important note is that tibbles should not be given row names.
Although tibbles have advantages compared to data.frames they are not always more suited to the task than data.frames. However, tibbles are generally always preferred over data.frames when using tidyverse packages.
Tibble homepage

title: Tibble
text:
Tibble example
Below is an example of:

Creating a basic tibble
Printing the tibble


#Create a tibble
tbl <- tibble::tibble(Day = c("Mon", "Tue", "Wed"),
              Hawks = c(3,7,2),
              Pigeons = c(52,21,61),
              Starlings = c(1,2,1))
#Print tibble
tbl

# A tibble: 3 × 4
  Day   Hawks Pigeons Starlings
  <chr> <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>
1 Mon       3      52         1
2 Tue       7      21         2
3 Wed       2      61         1
